raw_comment:
Part 2
 
 What do you wonder? I wonder what the term “colored” is referring to. Does this refer to everyone who is non-caucasian or does this refer to only African Americans? I am curious about this because I wonder if the numbers would change, especially in the MLS since it is more popular in Europe and South America than in the United States. Does this also lead to the fact that since soccer is not among the top three most popular sports in the U.S. and the understanding that many players are not from America, is the reason why the numbers are more equal among people of color and non-color in both players and coaches?  
 
I also wonder why the data for the WNBA is from 2019 and not 2020 like the rest of the data. Is this not as accurate because of the Coronavirus?
ace_sentences: I wonder what the term "colored" refers to.
I wonder whether "colored" refers to every non-Caucasian person.
I wonder whether "colored" refers only to African Americans.
I am curious about this question.
I think that the numbers could change if the meaning of "colored" changes.
MLS is more popular in Europe and South America than in the United States.
Many MLS players are not from the United States.
Soccer is not among the three most popular sports in the United States.
I wonder whether these facts explain why the numbers are more equal between people of color and non-people-of-color among players.
I wonder whether these facts explain why the numbers are more equal between people of color and non-people-of-color among coaches.
I also wonder why the WNBA data is from 2019.
The rest of the data is from 2020.
I wonder whether the WNBA data is less accurate because of the coronavirus.
